title.narrative: Urban Water Resilience: Providing WASH Services in Time of Severe Crisis

description.narrative:
**Long-term impact Water (WASH)**
Better performance of urban water and sanitation local corporation in times of crisis and health hazards by enhanced safe coverage of water and sewerage services, improved recovery of costs and systematic emergency preparedness – contributing to improved public health and water delivery for a population of 8 million people
​
**Medium-term impact**
- Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable Cooperation between (high and low performing) urban water and sanitation local corporations in Yemen and WEC consolidated under the aegis of the Yemen Water Partnership/MetaMeta
​
- Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce Fifteen Urban Water and Sanitation Local Corporations able to effectively deliver safe water and sanitation services in spite of the constraints of the war situation by capacitating concerned staff
​
- Water network better managed in 5 out of 15 Urban Water and Sanitation Local Corporations
​
- Sewerage facilities better managed in 5 out of 15 Urban Water and Sanitation Local Corporations

participating-org.narrative: Water and Environment Centre, Sana’a University, Yemen

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Booklet: Good Practices in Providing Urban Water Services during Severe Crisis
Dedicated Gender Mainstreaming Module
Extensive Resilience Training for WEC, Yemen
National Competition for Good Practice in Service Provision during Severe Crisis
New TMT+ Coordinator
Pilot Resilience Plan Template
Training the first batch - 25 participants from 5 water utilities and 5 relevant organisations
UNICEF/Mohamed Yasin
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value: This is not a final report.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative:
In this section (maximum 1000 words), please
**For TMT+:**
Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: A. TVET/HE organisations perform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment
A.E.5. Number of curricula for degree, non-degree and short courses revised/newly developed

description.narrative: Degree: bachelor's, master's and doctorate Non degree: Certificate and diploma

comment.narrative: 22-06-2021: We have developed 10 new training modules: i) emergency preparedness, ii) resilience planning, iii) gender-sensitive WaSH assessment, iv) water loss assessment, v) water safety planning, vi) Alternative energy: solar power, vii) water utility efficiency, viii) cost recovery, ix) Ibb and Sanaá case studies, and x) Resieliance good practices in Yemen.

title.narrative: A.S.2. Number of MoUs or other types of collaboration agreements signed (education, private, public, surrounding community)

comment.narrative: 22-06-2021: There are participation letters in the training activities from 10 water utilities and the ministry of water and environment.

title.narrative: A.E.4. Number of graduates delivered

comment.narrative: 22-06-2021: This is a non-degree training of trainers
100 trainees from 21 corporations successfully completed course/training, (50% female)

title.narrative: A.E.1. Number of (knowledge) institutions supported directly

comment.narrative: 22-06-2021: Water and Environment Center at Sana'a University
WEC and 21 WU are supported directly

title.narrative: A.E.3. Number of staff that have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes

comment.narrative: 22-06-2021: We are training lecturers of the water and environment centre and together with them training the staff of the water utilities. The staff are not administrative staff but core technical staff.

title.narrative: A.E.7. Student satisfaction

comment.narrative: 22-06-2021: We did use evaluation forms and feedback session at the end of each training. However, we did not use quantitative indicators. The feedback from the participants is very good, with some feedback for improvement. If we try to transform the impression of the participants on the training, we will be definitely above 80% satisfaction level. We try to attach two example training reports prepared by the project coordinator, which shows the general feedback for improvement. We also have recorded the training sessions.

title.narrative: A.E.6. Number of students enrolled in revised/newly developed study programmes
A. TVET/HE organisations perform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment
A.E.5. Number of curricula for degree, non-degree and short courses revised/newly developed

I. Education system is of good quality, relevant and accessible
I.E.1. Number of (knowledge) institutions that perform better

description.narrative: Write here the definition of a better performance

comment.narrative: WEC+21Water Utilities

title.narrative: I.S.2. Number of services to community

comment.narrative: Directly (2): water; and sanitation Indirectly (3): Education of young students; public health of the community (and cholera control): and Economy and commercial activities.

title.narrative: I.S.1. Number of beneficiaries in the society reached with knowledge, skills and techniques

comment.narrative: In the development of training curriculum of WEC, we targeted the largest utility in terms of population served (Sana’a) with a population of 3.2 million people. A resilience plan is already drafted and used for the utility 2021 plan. Next group will contain 5 utilities with a served population of 1.7 million. Next one will target another 5 utilities with 1.6 million people. After the project end, WEC alone will target third and forth batches (10 smaller utilities) with a population of 1.0 million people Then will be a regular module for WEC targeting other staff of the utilities and NGOs and other urban and rural service providers So beneficiaries are 6.5 million by the end of the project and 7.5 million one year after the project.

title.narrative: I.S.1. Number of beneficiaries in the society reached with knowledge, skills and techniques
W.4 People use safe drinking water and adequate sanitary facilities
W.4.1. Number of people trained in WASH
W.4.2. Number of WASH organisations indirectly strengthened

comment.narrative: At least WEC plus 11 water utilities will be directly trained by the end of the project and 21 water utilities one year after the project

title.narrative: III. Organisations key to (sectoral) inclusive development of partner countries are strengthened by inflow of enhanced workforce
III.I.2. % of alumni promoted to more strategic positions within their own organisation or other organisation

comment.narrative: 10% of alumni trainees in the ten Water and Sanitation Local Corporations (stage 2) to positions of head of sections

title.narrative: III.I.1. % of alumni who state that they have applied in their workplace the knowledge and skills gained from the interventions

comment.narrative: 80% of alumni trainees of the 21 Water And Sanitation Local Corporations (stage 2) state that they apply better emergency planning, service coverage measures and institutional performance

title.narrative: III.O.1. % employer satisfaction on suitability of the training for the organisation

comment.narrative: 80% of the 20 Water and Sanitation Local Corporations that had staff attending the TMT Plus training in Urban Water Resilience Management satisfaction (by Board of Directors) convinced of the appropriateness of the training)

title.narrative: III.O.5. % of alumni who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: Management of WEC as main service provider (stage 1 of the training) confident that it will continue the training and networking around urban water services in times of severe crisis

title.narrative: III.I.3. Narratives from alumni on policy and procedural changes, inclusive development, and innovations as a result of interventions
II. Partnerships between persons and organisations are inclusive and sustainable
II.P.1. Number of MoUs or other types of formal collaboration agreements exist 1, 3, 5 years after end of project

comment.narrative: Active membership of 15 Water and Sanitation Local Corporations in network on Urban Water Resilience under the Yemen Water Partnership

title.narrative: II.P.7. Number of Dutch training education organisations that have improved their training methods

comment.narrative: MetaMeta training services in urban water resiience in crisis situation

comment.narrative: WEC+21Water Utilities

title.narrative: I.S.2. Number of services to community

comment.narrative:
Directly (2): water; and sanitation
Indirectly (3): Education of young students; public health of the community (and cholera control): and Economy and commercial activities.

title.narrative: I.S.1. Number of beneficiaries in the society reached with knowledge, skills and techniques

comment.narrative:
In the development of training curriculum of WEC, we targeted the largest utility in terms of population served (Sana’a) with a population of 3.2 million people. A resilience plan is already drafted and used for the utility 2021 plan.
Next group will contain 5 utilities with a served population of 1.7 million. Next one will target another 5 utilities with 1.6 million people.
After the project end, WEC alone will target third and forth batches (10 smaller utilities) with a population of 1.0 million people
Then will be a regular module for WEC targeting other staff of the utilities and NGOs and other urban and rural service providers
So beneficiaries are 6.5 million by the end of the project and 7.5 million one year after the project.
